results.title: Luis Suarez gets nine-game ban for biting
results.content:
It's a case of the biter bit. Fifa slapped Luis Suárez with a nine-game international ban today for biting Italian defender Giorgio Chellini and suspended him from all football-related activity for four months, reports Roger Blitz.

He was also fined SFr 100,000 ($111,000).

The ban would appear to mean the end of the Uruguayan striker's participation in the rest of the World Cup. Uruguay plays Colombia in the round of 16 on Saturday.

But Fifa rules mean he can appeal the suspension, which may stay any ban until the outcome of that hearing.

However, Fifa was adamant he would play no further part in the World Cup.

The four-month ban from all football activity puts his club career at Liverpool in jeopardy and may affect a possible big-money summer transfer deal.

Fifa's independent disciplinary committee met on Wednesday and concluded he had breached rules on unsporting behaviour.

Sponsors Adidas and 888 may now decide to end their association with the controversial player.

It is the third time Suárez has been banned for biting.

Two years ago, he was banned for 10 games by England's Football Association for biting Chelsea defender Branislav Invanovic in a Premier League match.

He was also banned for seven matches in 2010 when biting a PSV Eindhoven opponent while playing for Ajax.

Suárez's lawyer claimed there was a conspiracy against his client, saying pressure for a ban had come from Italy and England, two teams knocked out of the World Cup by Uruguay and Costa Rica.
results.abstract: It's a case of the biter bit. Fifa slapped Luis Suárez with a nine-game international ban today for biting Italian defender Giorgio Chellini and suspended him from all football-related activity for four months, reports Roger Blitz.

results.title: Ikea raises minimum wage for US retail workers
results.content:
Its furniture may be cheap, but Ikea will pay more for its employees from January next year.

The international furniture retailer has announced it will raise its average minimum wage for US retail workers by $1.59 to $10.76. The increase would affect about half of Ikea's retail workers in the US.

The increase comes after a spat of protests across the US over minimum wage and after Barack Obama called income inequality "the defining issue of our time".

The company noted that the hourly wage would vary based on the cost of living in different US locations, but the 17 per cent rise would take its average minimum wage to $3.51 above the federal minimum wage.

The rate of increase was based on the MIT Living Wage Calculator, which takes housing ,food, medical and transportation costs into account along with taxes.

Ikea said it would be a "significant investment" but would not increase Ikea prices.

The change applies only to retail workers, it said, because all "non-retail locations - including five distribution centers, two service centers and a manufacturing facility - have hourly wage jobs that are already paying minimum wages above the local living wage."

Rob Olson, US acting president and CFO, said

The transition to the new minimum hourly wage structure is not only the right thing to do, it makes good business sense. We are basing our wages on our co-workers and their needs, rather than what the local employment market dictates. Our focus is to ensure that IKEA is a great place to work by providing an environment that develops our co-workers and also meets our customers' expectations. All of this contributes to our business success.
results.abstract: Its furniture may be cheap, but Ikea will pay more for its employees from January next year.

results.title: Thorning-Schmidt rules herself out of EU job
results.content:
Helle Thorning-Schmidt has ruled herself out of being in the running for a top European job, reports the FT's James Fontanella-Khan in Brussels.

Ms Thorning-Schmidt, the Danish prime minister, had been viewed as the odds-on favourite to become president of the European Council.

She said:

I'm not a candidate (for president of the council). I'm the prime minister of Denmark. It's a wonderful country and I'm very much hoping to win the next elections In Denmark.

For background on the contenders for Europe's top jobs, read this overview by the FT's Peter Spiegel.
results.abstract: Helle Thorning-Schmidt has ruled herself out of being in the running for a top European job, reports the FT's James Fontanella-Khan in Brussels.

results.title: Apple lowers iPod prices to boost appeal
results.content:
Apple is attempting to boost its flagging iPod lineup with the announcement of a 16Gb iPod touch model in "vibrant colours", with an added camera and a lower price.

IPod sales have been falling for years - with the more versatile iPhone-like touch model becoming the best-selling version of the music player.

The iPod touch had started at $229 in the US, but the new model costs $199 and comes in a range of colours now - pink, yellow, blue, red, silver and space grey. It also features the camera previously reserved for higher-spec models.

Prices on the 32Gb and 64Gb models have also been lowered significantly - from $299 to $249 and from $399 to $299 respectively.
results.abstract: Apple is attempting to boost its flagging iPod lineup with the announcement of a 16Gb iPod touch model in "vibrant colours", with an added camera and a lower price.

results.title: "Pope of Art" arrested
results.content:
A prominent German art consultant was arrested on suspicion of fraud after the widow of Aldi Nord heir Berthold Albrecht accused him of adding "concealed surcharges" to the sales of artworks and vintage cars, reports the FT's Jeevan Vasagar in Berlin.

Helge Achenbach, a consultant based in Düsseldorf who has advised companies and private clients on art acquisitions for decades, was arrested earlier this month and remains in custody.

In a statement, a spokeswoman for Mr Achenbach's company Achenbach Kunstberatung said that he faced a criminal complaint from Mr Albrecht's widow.

The consultant is accused of adding hidden surcharges to sales, the statement said.

It also said the consultant had a "close and friendly" relationship with the discount supermarket heir, who died in 2012, and that he was confident the allegations would turn out to be unwarranted.

The company's statement said that all the art objects and vintage cars that Berthold Albrecht acquired increased in value considerably during his lifetime.

"Their present value is many times higher than the purchase prices paid at the time by Berthold Albrecht"

Mr Achenbach is nicknamed the "Kunstpapst" – or 'pope of art' – and prides himself on his close relationships with clients and artists. According to his company he has advised on the acquisition of paintings by Gerhard Richter, Germany's most famous living artist, and the public display in Germany of Jeff Koons' monumental sculpture Puppy.

Mr Achenbach was arrested on his return from the German team's World Cup base in Brazil, where he was involved in an art project bringing together German and Brazilian artists.
results.abstract: A prominent German art consultant was arrested on suspicion of fraud after the widow of Aldi Nord heir Berthold Albrecht accused him of adding "concealed surcharges" to the sales of artworks and vintage cars, reports the FT's Jeevan Vasagar in Berlin.

results.title: US consumer spending undershoots forecasts
results.content:
So much for second-quarter acceleration.

Consumer spending in the US grew at a slower pace than economists had expected in May, despite an acceleration in incomes, according to a report from the Commerce Department on Thursday.

The figures showed a 0.2 per cent rise in spending and 0.4 per cent rise in incomes in May from a month earlier. While the income gains were expected, economists on Wall Street had forecast a 0.4 per cent rise in spending.

The results may trigger a wave of adjustments to second-quarter growth forecasts, which were projected to show a sharp reversal from the contraction of the first three months of the year.

Strategists with TD Securities said the report, which showed the savings rate at eight month high, would weigh on second quarter GDP forecasts.

The spending side of the report appears to be weaker even on a real basis...hinting at the potential for weaker than anticipated consumer expenditure during Q2, likely leading to some downgrades to Q2 growth expectations

A separate report from the labour department showed 312,000 new claims for unemployment benefits, a slight decline from a week earlier.

results.title: Fed's Lacker: What labour market slack?
results.content:
There is not much more that monetary policy can do for the unemployed.

That is the message from Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker, the policy hawk who had no qualms tapering the central bank's stimulus measures last December.

In a speech on Thursday, Mr Lacker, who is not a voting member of the Fed this year, said slack in the labour force was consistent with the current unemployment level and there was little more that monetary policy could do to raise employment.

My reading of the evidence is that much of what we have observed over the past five years reflects structural changes in the economy that would have been difficult for monetary policy to offset.

The Fed, under its dual mandate, has been under pressure to balance employment and inflation levels. With the latter beginning to firm – a reading of inflation in May showed a 2.1 per cent year-on-year rise – economists have instead turned their focus to slack in the workforce, or those out-of-work who would like to work.

Fed chair Janet Yellen has argued that some slack remains, although the 1.1m jobs created since the start of the year have set investors wondering how much is left, and when the labour market will begin to tighten.

Structural factors affecting the market, including the retirement of many baby boomers, may be to blame for the still elevated unemployment rate, Mr Lacker said.

There is more slack than indicated by the standard unemployment rate, but there always is, and there seems to be no more additional slack now than is typically associated with the current level of the unemployment rate.
results.abstract: There is not much more that monetary policy can do for the unemployed.

results.title: Imperial Tobacco sets Logista range in €1.9bn IPO
results.content:
Imperial Tobacco has announced the price range for its flotation of its southern European logistics subsidiary Logista on the Spanish stock exchange, with a mid-point price that values the business at €1.86bn.

Imperial said the range would be €12.50 to €15.50 a share for the initial public offering, with the final price determined around July 10.

Imperial Tobacco's subsidiary Altadis intends to sell up to 30 per cent of its shares to institutional investors in the IPO and a maximum of 39.8m shares are being offered

Imperial had been reviewing its options for the Logista business for months. It acquired it in 2008 as part of its £11bn takeover of Spain's Altadis.
results.abstract: Imperial Tobacco has announced the price range for its flotation of its southern European logistics subsidiary Logista on the Spanish stock exchange, with a mid-point price that values the business at €1.86bn.

results.title: Indian central bank cautions on state banks
results.content:
India's central bank may have supported the new government by holding interest rates on hold but it isn't going to pretend everything is rosy, as Narendra Modi takes the reins in New Delhi promising to revive growth in Asia's third largest economy.

Avantika Chilkoti reports that the new report on financial stability, out on Thursday, warns that public sector banks [PSBs] are still in deep trouble. A study conducted in April shows that asset quality at these institutions remains in the 'high' risk category.

India's financial system remains stable, though the banking sector is facing some major challenges, mainly relating to public sector banks.

Under a severe stress scenario, the level of gross non-performing advances as a percentage of total gross advances could rise to 6.1 per cent by March from 4.6 per cent a year earlier.

These banks could have the lowest ratio of capital to risk weighted assets at about 9.4 per cent by March 2015 - a whisker above the minimum requirement of 9 per cent.

The report says:

Efforts to de-stress the banking sector need to be complemented by necessary steps for developing bond markets. With the Indian government showing a greater resolve for fiscal consolidation, there is a strong case for encouraging PSBs to approach capital markets for meeting their additional capital requirements under pillars I and II of Basel III.
results.abstract: India's central bank may have supported the new government by holding interest rates on hold but it isn't going to pretend everything is rosy, as Narendra Modi takes the reins in New Delhi promising to revive growth in Asia's third largest economy.

results.title: Bulgaria selling first eurobond in two years
results.content:
The EU's poorest member state has attracted €3.75bn in orders for a bond expected to be north of €1bn in size against a choppy financial and political backdrop, reports Elaine Moore.

The euro-denominated September 2024 bond sale was launched on Thursday and is expected to be priced later this afternoon. The pricing has been revised from the initial 170 basis points over mid-swaps - the eurozone's pricing benchmark - to around 160.

Bulgaria has undergone political and economic upheaval recently including a rating downgrade by Standard & Poor's this month to one notch above junk status.

Last week the country nationalised a local bank, Corporate Commercial Bank, in the hope of avoiding a large scale bank run, which has sent bond yields climbing from the record low touched in mid-May.

Citigroup, HSBC and JP Morgan are lead managers on the sale.
results.abstract: The EU's poorest member state has attracted €3.75bn in orders for a bond expected to be north of €1bn in size against a choppy financial and political backdrop, reports Elaine Moore.
